Interim Devaluation Allowance of Employees
Act, No. 0 of 1968
AN AoT 10 PROVIDE FOR THE PAYMENT, OTHERWISE THAN
BY EMERGENCY LAWS, OF AN INTERIM DEVALUATION
ALLOWANCE BY EMPLOYERS TO INDUSTRIAL AND AGRI-
CULTURAL EMPLOYEES, AND FOR MATTERS CONNECTED
THEREWITH OR INCIDENTAL THERETO,
[Date of Assent: November 10, 1968]
BE it enacted by the Queens Most Excellent Majesty,
by and with the advice and consent of the Senate and
1 House of Representatives of Ceylon in this present
Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the
seme, as follows:
4. This Act may be cited os the Interim Devalua- ster rite
tion Allowance of Employees Act, No. 40 of 1068, and 104 de ot
shall come into operation on such date as may be
appointed by the Minister by Order published in the
Gazette, in this Act referred to as the appointed
fate,
2, (1) The Commissioner shall be the competent compenas
authority for the purposes of this Act. soubany.
(2) The competent authority may delegate to any
officer of the Labour Department ny power, function
or duty conferred or imposed on such authority by
this Act.
8. The provisions of this Act shall have force and this Act
effect notwithstanding anything in any other written bf
Jaw, or in any contract of employment, whether oral, smwits-
written, express or implied; and acoordingly, in the trdiig sor
event of any conflict or inconsistency between such ste writaa

such provisions shall to the extent of such inconsistency
prevail over any such other law or such contract.
3. (1) On and after the appointed date, every Interim
employer of any industrial or agricultural employes <artnstin
1, in respect of each month, pay such employee an
interim allowance, in this Act Teferred to as av

following rates:-
{@) where such employee is an industrial employee,
other than a pisoe rated industrial empleyee,
and

and applicable in the case of such

(@ where such employee is a piece rated industrial

of each complete unit of four rupees compris.
ing his monthly remuneration, so, however,
thet the maximum amount payable to such
employee as an interim devaluation allowance
in respect of any month shali not exceed the

cents by the number of days speolied in res-
Beet of that month in Part ITI of that
chedule, or by the number of days such
employee has worked in that month, which-
ever is greater; or
() where such employee is a piece rated agrienltural
employee, at the rate of thirty cents in respect
of each complete unit of two rupees and
seventy cents comprising his monthly remu-
neration, so, however, that the maximum
amount payable to such employes as an
interim devaluation allowance in respect of
any month shall not exceed the amount deter-
mined by malkiplying thirty cents by the
number of days specified in respect of that
month in Part ITI of that Schedule, or by the
number of days such employee has worked in
that month, whichever is greater:

Provided, however, that any euch employee who is
entitled to 3 cost, of Living allowanoe determined in

ages Boards Ordinance, shall not be entitled, for the

allowance paid for the said month of December and

employee shall, in respect of that month, be entitled,
in addition to the interim devaluation allowance, to
be paid the amount of such excess.
(2) The interim devaluation allowance shall be
deemed to be part of the cost of living allowance

rice Index Figure, or the special allowance payable
under the decisions of the Wages Boards constituted
ander the Wages Boards Ordinance for all purposes,
whether of any written law or otherwise, for which
sach cost of living allowance, or special allowance,
as the case may be, is taken into account.

Special 9, Every person, who having been an industrial or
geviieee agricultural employee of any employer on the day
gitanitin immediately prior to December 1, 1967, shall, for so
long as he continues to be an employee of such
employer, be so continued in employment by such
employer on such terms and conditions relating to
salary, allowances or other payments in money by
whatsoever name or designation called, excluding the
interim devaluation allowance, as are not less
favourable than such employee had or enjoyed on the
day immediately prior to that date.
Fails 10 ey 40, (1) Any employer who fails to pay any sum
fins dm ands: yeguired to be paid to an employee of such employer
ince to under section 4 or who fails to comply with the provi-
woah & sions of section 9 shall be guilty of an offence and shall
be Hable to a fine not exceeding one thousand rupees
or to imprisonment of either description for a term
not exceeding six months or to both such fine and
imprisonment, and shall, in addition, be liable to a
fine not exceeding fifty rupees for each day on which
the offence is continued after conviction.
n the conviction by a court of an employer
toon Poffence by reason ot the failure of auch.
employer to pay any eum required to be paid to an
employee of such employer under section 4, the court
may, in addition to any other penalty which it may
have imposed for such offence, order such employer
to pay such sum to such employee, within period
sperified in the order, and if such sum is not so paid,
auch sum may be recovered and paid to such employee
on the order of the court as if it were fine imposed
by the court.

ed, a false return or a return containing any
false statement,
shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fin
not exceeding one thousand rupees or to imprisonment
of either description for a term not exceeding six
months or to both such fine and imprisonment.
42. (1) Where an offence for which ian employer shitty ot
is liable under this Act has in fact been committed by S227""
some agent of the employer or other person, that
agent or other person sl be liable to be proceeded
against for the offence in the same manner as if he
were the employer, and either together with, or before
Or after the conviction of the employer, and shail be
liable on conviction to the same punishment as that to
which the employer is liable.
. (Q) Where an employer who is charged with an
offence under this Act, proves to the satisfaction of the
court that he has used due diligence to enforce the
execution of this Act and that the offence was in fact
committad he hice arent or some other berson Without
